docs.text: tag-ai-literacy Initial mkdocs for AI Literacy site Project Overview A WordPress plugin that creates an educational resource using MkDocs. This project provides a set of markdown files (starting with glossary.md) to help clarify, educate, and elucidate AI terminology, benefits, risks, and strategies . An AI literacy resource aimed at making AI concepts accessible and understandable. 🎯 Vision Create a comprehensive, accessible resource that demystifies artificial intelligence for everyone. Whether you're a business leader evaluating AI solutions, a developer building AI-powered applications, or someone curious about AI's impact on society, this resource provides clear, jargon-free explanations of AI concepts. Our Goals: Clarify complex AI terminology into understandable language Educate on both the capabilities and limitations of AI technologies Elucidate the real-world benefits, risks, and ethical considerations Empower informed decision-making about AI adoption and usage Build a foundation for AI literacy that grows with the technology This is a living resource that will evolve as AI technology advances, ensuring the content remains relevant and practical.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Create a comprehensive, accessible resource that demystifies artificial intelligence for everyone. Whether you're a business leader evaluating AI solutions, a developer building AI-powered applications, or someone curious about AI's impact on society, this resource provides clear, jargon-free explanations of AI concepts. Our Goals: Clarify complex AI terminology into understandable language Educate on both the capabilities and limitations of AI technologies Elucidate the real-world benefits, risks, and ethical considerations Empower informed decision-making about AI adoption and usage Build a foundation for AI literacy that grows with the technology This is a living resource that will evolve as AI technology advances, ensuring the content remains relevant and practical.
docs.title: 🎯 Vision

docs.text: AI Benefits and Risks Understanding both the potential benefits and risks of artificial intelligence is essential for responsible adoption and use. This guide provides a balanced view of AI's impact on individuals, organizations, and society. ✅ Benefits of AI 1. Enhanced Productivity and Efficiency What It Means: AI automates routine tasks, processes information faster than humans, and enables people to focus on higher-value work. Real-World Impact: - Developers write code 30-50% faster with AI coding assistants - Customer service teams handle more inquiries with AI chatbots - Document analysis that took hours now takes minutes - Data entry and processing automation saves countless work hours Example: A marketing team using AI writing tools can produce first drafts in minutes, allowing more time for strategy and creative refinement. 2. Improved Accessibility What It Means: AI makes technology and information more accessible to people with different abilities, language barriers, or limited technical skills. Real-World Impact: - Screen readers with AI provide better context for visually impaired users - Real-time translation breaks down language barriers - Voice interfaces make technology accessible to those with mobility challenges - AI-powered captioning and transcription helps deaf and hard-of-hearing communities Example: A non-technical business owner can now build a functional website using AI tools that understand natural language instructions. 3. Advanced Problem-Solving What It Means: AI can analyze vast amounts of data, identify patterns humans might miss, and propose solutions to complex problems. Real-World Impact: - Medical diagnosis assistance by analyzing thousands of cases - Climate modeling and environmental prediction - Drug discovery accelerated from years to months - Financial fraud detection in real-time Example: AlphaFold solved the protein folding problem, a 50-year challenge in biology, opening new possibilities for drug development. 4. 24/7 Availability What It Means: AI systems can operate continuously without breaks, providing instant responses and support around the clock. Real-World Impact: - Customer support available at any time - Continuous monitoring of critical systems - Learning resources available when students need them - Global collaboration across time zones Example: A customer in Tokyo gets instant support for a product from a US company at 3 AM local time. 5. Personalization at Scale What It Means: AI can tailor experiences, recommendations, and content to individual preferences and needs for millions of users simultaneously. Real-World Impact: - Personalized learning paths adapt to each student's pace - Content recommendations match individual interests - Customized health and fitness guidance - Targeted product suggestions improve shopping experience Example: Educational platforms adjust difficulty and teaching style based on how each student learns best. 6. Cost Reduction What It Means: AI automation and efficiency gains can significantly reduce operational costs for businesses and organizations. Real-World Impact: - Reduced need for repetitive manual labor - Lower customer service costs - Decreased error rates and associated costs - More efficient resource allocation Example: Small businesses can now afford capabilities (like 24/7 customer service) previously only available to large enterprises. 7. Innovation and Creativity What It Means: AI serves as a creative partner, helping humans explore new ideas, iterate quickly, and push creative boundaries. Real-World Impact: - Artists create new forms of digital art - Musicians experiment with AI-assisted composition - Writers overcome creative blocks with AI brainstorming - Designers rapidly prototype and iterate concepts Example: A graphic designer uses AI to generate dozens of logo variations, then refines the most promising concepts with their expertise. 8. Scientific Discovery What It Means: AI accelerates research by processing massive datasets, identifying patterns, and suggesting hypotheses that humans might not consider. Real-World Impact: - Faster development of new materials - Climate change modeling and prediction - Astronomical discoveries from telescope data - Genomic research and personalized medicine Example: AI systems analyzing telescope data have discovered exoplanets and astronomical phenomena that human researchers missed. ⚠️ Risks and Concerns 1. Bias and Discrimination What It Means: AI systems can perpetuate or amplify existing biases present in their training data, leading to unfair or discriminatory outcomes. Real-World Impact: - Hiring AI tools may discriminate based on gender or race - Facial recognition systems work less accurately for certain demographics - Loan approval systems may reflect historical lending discrimination - Criminal justice algorithms may show racial bias Example: An AI resume screening tool trained on historical data might favor male candidates for technical roles, perpetuating gender imbalance. Mitigation: Diverse training data, bias testing, human oversight, and transparency in AI decision-making. 2. Privacy and Data Security What It Means: AI systems often require large amounts of data, raising concerns about how personal information is collected, stored, and used. Real-World Impact: - Personal conversations with AI may be stored or used for training - Facial recognition technology enables mass surveillance - Data breaches expose sensitive AI training data - Inference attacks can reveal information about training data Example: An AI service stores all your conversations and later experiences a data breach, exposing sensitive information you shared. Mitigation: Data minimization, encryption, clear privacy policies, user control over data, and adherence to regulations like GDPR. 3. Misinformation and Deepfakes What It Means: AI can generate convincing but false text, images, audio, and video, making it harder to distinguish truth from fiction. Real-World Impact: - AI-generated fake news spreads rapidly - Deepfake videos can damage reputations or spread propaganda - Synthetic audio can impersonate voices for fraud - Academic dishonesty through AI-written papers Example: A deepfake video of a CEO making false statements causes stock price manipulation and investor harm. Mitigation: Digital watermarking, verification tools, media literacy education, and platform moderation policies. 4. Job Displacement What It Means: AI automation may eliminate certain jobs faster than new ones are created, requiring workforce adaptation and retraining. Real-World Impact: - Automation of routine office tasks - Reduced need for certain customer service roles - Changes in creative industry employment - Manufacturing and logistics automation Example: A company replaces its call center staff with AI chatbots, leaving hundreds without employment. Mitigation: Reskilling programs, focus on uniquely human skills, gradual transition periods, and social safety nets. 5. Lack of Transparency ("Black Box" Problem) What It Means: Many AI systems, especially deep learning models, make decisions in ways that are difficult or impossible to explain or understand. Real-World Impact: - Medical diagnoses without clear reasoning - Loan denials without explanation - Content moderation decisions that seem arbitrary - Legal and ethical accountability challenges Example: An AI system denies someone's mortgage application, but even the bank can't explain exactly why the AI made that decision. Mitigation: Explainable AI research, human-in-the-loop systems, regulatory requirements for transparency, and audit trails. 6. Over-Reliance and Skill Degradation What It Means: Excessive dependence on AI may lead to loss of critical human skills, judgment, and the ability to function without AI assistance. Real-World Impact: - Reduced critical thinking when blindly trusting AI - Loss of fundamental skills (writing, math, navigation) - Decreased human judgment in decision-making - Vulnerability when AI systems fail Example: Students who always use AI for writing may never develop strong writing skills themselves, limiting their career options. Mitigation: Education on appropriate AI use, maintaining human oversight, and preserving opportunities to practice core skills. 7. Security Vulnerabilities What It Means: AI systems can be targets for attacks, manipulation, or misuse, with potentially serious consequences. Real-World Impact: - Adversarial attacks fool AI systems - AI used to create sophisticated phishing or malware - Manipulation of AI training data (data poisoning) - AI-powered cyberattacks Example: Attackers use carefully crafted inputs to fool autonomous vehicle AI systems into misidentifying stop signs as speed limit signs. Mitigation: Adversarial training, security testing, input validation, and continuous monitoring. 8. Environmental Impact What It Means: Training and running large AI models requires significant computational resources, leading to substantial energy consumption and carbon emissions. Real-World Impact: - Large language models consume energy equivalent to hundreds of homes - GPU production and disposal creates e-waste - Data center energy demands strain power grids - Carbon footprint of AI development Example: Training a single large AI model can emit as much carbon as five cars over their entire lifetimes. Mitigation: Energy-efficient algorithms, renewable energy for data centers, smaller specialized models, and carbon offsetting. 9. Concentration of Power What It Means: AI development is dominated by a few large tech companies and nations, creating imbalances in access, control, and benefit distribution. Real-World Impact: - Small businesses can't compete with big tech AI capabilities - Developing nations lag in AI adoption - Few companies control foundational AI models - Economic benefits concentrate among AI leaders Example: Only a handful of companies can afford to train cutting-edge AI models, giving them outsized influence over the technology's direction. Mitigation: Open-source AI models, international cooperation, support for academic research, and antitrust considerations. 10. Existential and Alignment Risks What It Means: As AI systems become more capable, questions arise about whether we can ensure they remain aligned with human values and interests. Real-World Impact: - AI systems pursuing objectives in unexpected harmful ways - Difficulty in specifying human values precisely - Potential loss of human control over highly capable AI - Long-term risks from artificial general intelligence (AGI) Example: An AI system optimized to "maximize engagement" might spread divisive content because it achieves the narrow goal, even though it harms society. Mitigation: AI safety research, value alignment studies, careful development practices, and international governance frameworks. ⚖️ Balancing Benefits and Risks Responsible AI Use Framework For Individuals: 1. Verify Important Information - Don't blindly trust AI outputs 2. Understand Limitations - Know what AI can and cannot do 3. Protect Privacy - Be mindful of what data you share 4. Maintain Skills - Use AI as a tool, not a replacement for learning 5. Consider Ethics - Think about the broader impact of your AI use For Organizations: 1. Implement Oversight - Human review of AI decisions 2. Test for Bias - Regularly audit AI systems for fairness 3. Ensure Transparency - Clear communication about AI use 4. Provide Training - Educate staff on appropriate AI use 5. Plan for Impact - Consider effects on employees and stakeholders For Society: 1. Develop Regulations - Thoughtful governance frameworks 2. Promote Research - Support AI safety and ethics research 3. Ensure Accessibility - Prevent AI from widening inequalities 4. Foster Literacy - Widespread education about AI 5. Enable Accountability - Clear lines of responsibility for AI harms 🎯 Key Takeaways AI Offers Tremendous Benefits When used responsibly, AI can enhance productivity, solve complex problems, improve accessibility, and drive innovation across every field. But Requires Careful Consideration The risks—from bias and privacy concerns to job displacement and security vulnerabilities—demand thoughtful approaches to development and deployment. Balance Is Essential The goal isn't to avoid AI, but to harness its benefits while actively mitigating its risks through education, oversight, and responsible practices. The future of AI depends on informed, thoughtful decisions made today. Understanding both benefits and risks empowers better choices about when, how, and why to use AI technologies.

docs.title: Responsible AI Use Framework

docs.text: AI Offers Tremendous Benefits When used responsibly, AI can enhance productivity, solve complex problems, improve accessibility, and drive innovation across every field. But Requires Careful Consideration The risks—from bias and privacy concerns to job displacement and security vulnerabilities—demand thoughtful approaches to development and deployment. Balance Is Essential The goal isn't to avoid AI, but to harness its benefits while actively mitigating its risks through education, oversight, and responsible practices. The future of AI depends on informed, thoughtful decisions made today. Understanding both benefits and risks empowers better choices about when, how, and why to use AI technologies.
docs.title: 🎯 Key Takeaways

docs.text: AI Glossary A comprehensive guide to essential AI terminology, designed to make artificial intelligence concepts accessible to everyone. Core AI Terms 1. Artificial Intelligence (AI) Definition: Computer systems designed to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence, such as understanding language, recognizing patterns, making decisions, and solving problems. In Practice: AI powers voice assistants like Siri and Alexa, recommendation systems on Netflix and Amazon, and autonomous vehicles. AI systems learn from data and experience rather than following only explicit programmed instructions. Key Point: AI is an umbrella term covering many technologies, from simple rule-based systems to advanced machine learning models. 2. Machine Learning (ML) Definition: A subset of AI where computers learn patterns from data without being explicitly programmed for every scenario. The system improves its performance as it processes more data. In Practice: Email spam filters learn to identify spam by analyzing thousands of examples. Fraud detection systems recognize suspicious transactions by learning from historical patterns. Key Point: Instead of writing rules for every possible scenario, ML systems discover patterns automatically from examples. 3. Large Language Model (LLM) Definition: Advanced AI models trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like language. These models can write, summarize, translate, answer questions, and perform various language tasks. In Practice: ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini are LLMs that can have conversations, write code, analyze documents, and assist with creative tasks. They process language by understanding context and relationships between words. Key Point: LLMs don't "know" facts like a database; they generate responses based on patterns learned from training data. 4. Natural Language Processing (NLP) Definition: The branch of AI focused on enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language in a meaningful way. In Practice: NLP powers chatbots, language translation services (like Google Translate), sentiment analysis of customer reviews, and voice-to-text systems. Key Point: NLP bridges the gap between human communication and computer understanding, making human-computer interaction more natural. 5. Deep Learning Definition: A specialized type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks with multiple layers to learn increasingly complex patterns from data. In Practice: Deep learning enables facial recognition in photos, voice recognition in smart speakers, and self-driving car vision systems. It's particularly effective for image, speech, and language tasks. Key Point: "Deep" refers to the multiple layers in the neural network, each learning different levels of abstraction from the data. 6. Neural Network Definition: A computing system inspired by biological brain neurons, consisting of interconnected nodes (artificial neurons) organized in layers that process and transform information. In Practice: Neural networks power image recognition, speech synthesis, and pattern detection. Each layer of the network learns to recognize different features, from simple edges to complex objects. Key Point: While inspired by the brain, artificial neural networks are mathematical models that work quite differently from biological neurons. 7. Training Data Definition: The collection of examples, information, and content used to teach an AI system how to perform its task. The quality and diversity of training data directly impacts the AI's performance. In Practice: An image recognition system is trained on thousands of labeled photos. A language model is trained on books, articles, and web content. Medical AI is trained on patient records and diagnostic images. Key Point: Biased or limited training data leads to biased or limited AI capabilities. "Garbage in, garbage out" applies to AI training. 8. Prompt Definition: The input text or instruction given to an AI system (especially LLMs) to generate a response or perform a task. Effective prompting is crucial for getting useful AI outputs. In Practice: Asking ChatGPT "Write a professional email declining a meeting" is a prompt. More detailed prompts ("Write a polite, 3-sentence email declining next week's meeting due to schedule conflicts") typically yield better results. Key Point: Prompt engineering—crafting effective prompts—is an emerging skill for working with AI systems effectively. 9. Fine-tuning Definition: The process of taking a pre-trained AI model and further training it on specific, specialized data to adapt it for particular tasks or domains. In Practice: A general language model might be fine-tuned on medical literature to better understand and generate medical content, or on legal documents to assist with legal research. Key Point: Fine-tuning is more efficient than training from scratch and allows customization of AI models for specific use cases. 10. Hallucination Definition: When an AI system generates information that sounds plausible but is actually incorrect, fabricated, or inconsistent with reality. A critical limitation to be aware of when using AI. In Practice: An LLM might confidently cite non-existent research papers, create fake statistics, or describe events that never happened—all while presenting the information convincingly. Key Point: Always verify important information from AI systems against reliable sources. AI confidence doesn't equal accuracy. Using This Glossary This glossary is designed to be: Accessible: Plain language explanations without assuming technical background Practical: Real-world examples showing how concepts apply Honest: Including both capabilities and limitations Evolving: Updated as AI technology and terminology develop For more detailed information on any term, or to suggest additions, please refer to the project documentation.
docs.title: Glossary

docs.title: Using This Glossary

docs.text: AI Products and Services A comprehensive overview of major AI products and services available today, organized by category and use case. 💬 Conversational AI & LLMs Anthropic's Claude Website: claude.ai What It Does: Claude is a conversational AI assistant built with a focus on safety, accuracy, and helpfulness. It excels at long-form content analysis, coding assistance, and nuanced conversation. Key Features: - Extended context windows (up to 200K tokens for analyzing long documents) - Strong performance on coding and technical tasks - Constitutional AI training for safer, more aligned outputs - Claude Code CLI tool for developer workflows Pricing: Free tier available; Claude Pro subscription for extended usage ($20/month) Best For: Research, document analysis, coding assistance, creative writing, complex reasoning tasks OpenAI's ChatGPT Website: chat.openai.com What It Does: ChatGPT is the most widely-used conversational AI, capable of answering questions, writing content, coding, and much more. Built on the GPT-4 model family. Key Features: - GPT-4o for multimodal capabilities (text, images, voice) - Custom GPTs for specialized tasks - DALL-E integration for image generation - Plugin ecosystem for extended capabilities - Advanced data analysis and code execution Pricing: Free tier with GPT-3.5; ChatGPT Plus ($20/month) for GPT-4 access Best For: General purpose AI assistance, content creation, brainstorming, coding, education Google's Gemini (formerly Bard) Website: gemini.google.com What It Does: Google's conversational AI integrated with Google's search capabilities and workspace tools. Key Features: - Deep integration with Google Search for current information - Multimodal understanding (text, images, video) - Google Workspace integration - Extremely large context windows (Gemini 1.5) Pricing: Free tier available; Gemini Advanced with Google One AI Premium ($19.99/month) Best For: Research with web search, Google Workspace integration, analyzing large documents Microsoft Copilot Website: copilot.microsoft.com What It Does: Microsoft's AI assistant powered by GPT-4, integrated across Microsoft products and services. Key Features: - Integrated into Windows, Edge, Bing search - Microsoft 365 integration (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) - Free access to GPT-4 capabilities through Bing - Image generation with DALL-E Pricing: Free in Bing/Edge; Microsoft 365 Copilot ($30/user/month for business) Best For: Microsoft ecosystem users, web search with AI assistance, productivity workflows 👨‍💻 AI Coding Assistants GitHub Copilot Website: github.com/features/copilot What It Does: AI pair programmer that suggests code completions, entire functions, and helps debug code directly in your IDE. Key Features: - Real-time code suggestions as you type - Supports dozens of programming languages - Context-aware based on your codebase - Chat interface for code explanations - IDE integration (VS Code, JetBrains, Neovim, etc.) Pricing: $10/month individual; $19/user/month business; Free for verified students/open source maintainers Best For: Professional developers, learning to code, accelerating development workflows Cursor Website: cursor.sh What It Does: AI-first code editor built on VS Code with advanced AI features for writing, editing, and understanding code. Key Features: - Codebase-aware AI that understands your entire project - Natural language code editing - Multi-file editing capabilities - Terminal integration - Built on VS Code (compatible with extensions) Pricing: Free tier available; Pro plan $20/month Best For: Developers wanting AI-native editing experience, large codebase navigation Replit Website: replit.com What It Does: Cloud-based development environment with AI assistance for building, deploying, and hosting applications entirely in the browser. Key Features: - AI code generation and debugging - Instant hosting and deployment - Collaborative coding - Supports 50+ programming languages - No local setup required Pricing: Free tier; Replit Core $15/month for enhanced features Best For: Learning to code, rapid prototyping, building full-stack apps without local setup Codeium Website: codeium.com What It Does: Free AI code completion tool similar to GitHub Copilot, supporting 70+ programming languages. Key Features: - Unlimited free usage for individuals - Fast code completions - IDE integration - Chat feature for code explanations - Local processing option for privacy Pricing: Free for individuals; Team/Enterprise plans available Best For: Developers wanting free AI code assistance, privacy-conscious users 🎨 Image Generation & Design Midjourney Website: midjourney.com What It Does: Leading AI image generation service known for artistic, high-quality outputs. Operates through Discord. Key Features: - Photorealistic and artistic image generation - Style consistency and variation control - Community gallery and inspiration - Image upscaling and variations Pricing: Starts at $10/month (Basic plan) Best For: Artists, designers, marketing materials, concept art, creative exploration DALL-E 3 Website: openai.com/dall-e-3 (integrated in ChatGPT) What It Does: OpenAI's image generation model, accessible through ChatGPT, known for understanding complex prompts. Key Features: - Natural language prompt understanding - Integrated directly in ChatGPT - Iterative refinement through conversation - Commercial usage rights Pricing: Included with ChatGPT Plus ($20/month) Best For: ChatGPT users, conversational image creation, prompt refinement Adobe Firefly Website: firefly.adobe.com What It Does: Adobe's AI image generation and editing tools, integrated into Creative Cloud apps. Key Features: - Commercially safe (trained on licensed content) - Integration with Photoshop, Illustrator - Generative fill, expand, and recolor - Style matching Pricing: Limited free generation; included with Creative Cloud subscriptions Best For: Professional designers, Adobe Creative Cloud users, commercial projects Stable Diffusion Website: stability.ai What It Does: Open-source image generation model that can be run locally or through various interfaces. Key Features: - Completely open source - Run locally on your hardware - Extensive customization and fine-tuning - Large community and model variants Pricing: Free (open source); Stability AI has paid API services Best For: Technical users, customization, privacy, learning AI image generation 🎬 Video & Audio AI Runway ML Website: runwayml.com What It Does: AI-powered creative suite for video editing, generation, and effects. Key Features: - Text-to-video generation - Video-to-video transformation - Background removal and object tracking - Image animation Pricing: Free tier; Pro plans start at $15/month Best For: Video creators, filmmakers, content creators, visual effects ElevenLabs Website: elevenlabs.io What It Does: Advanced AI voice generation and cloning for realistic speech synthesis. Key Features: - Natural-sounding voice generation - Voice cloning from samples - Multilingual support - Emotion and intonation control Pricing: Free tier; Starter plan $5/month Best For: Podcasters, audiobook creation, voiceovers, content localization 🔍 AI-Powered Search & Research Perplexity AI Website: perplexity.ai What It Does: AI-powered search engine that provides sourced, conversational answers to questions. Key Features: - Citations and sources for all answers - Follow-up questions - Academic and research modes - Real-time web information Pricing: Free tier; Pro plan $20/month for GPT-4 and unlimited searches Best For: Research, fact-checking, current events, sourced information Notion AI Website: notion.so/product/ai What It Does: AI writing and organization assistant integrated directly into Notion workspace. Key Features: - Writing assistance and editing - Summarization of documents - Action items extraction - Database population Pricing: $10/member/month add-on to Notion workspace Best For: Notion users, note-taking, knowledge management, team collaboration 🤖 Specialized AI Tools Grammarly Website: grammarly.com What It Does: AI-powered writing assistant for grammar, spelling, style, and tone. Key Features: - Real-time grammar and spelling correction - Tone and clarity suggestions - Plagiarism detection - Browser extension and app integrations Pricing: Free tier; Premium $12/month; Business plans available Best For: Writers, professionals, students, business communication Jasper AI Website: jasper.ai What It Does: AI writing platform for marketing content, blogs, and business copy. Key Features: - Marketing-focused templates - Brand voice customization - SEO optimization - Team collaboration features Pricing: Plans start at $39/month Best For: Marketing teams, content creators, SEO specialists, business writing 📊 Choosing the Right AI Tool Consider these factors when selecting an AI product or service: Use Case - What specific task do you need to accomplish? Integration - Does it work with your existing tools and workflow? Pricing - Does it fit your budget? Many offer free tiers for exploration Privacy - How is your data used? Is it used for training? Quality - Does it meet your quality standards for your use case? Support - What level of documentation and customer support is available? Start Free Most AI services offer free tiers or trials. Start with free options to understand what works for your needs before committing to paid subscriptions. Verify Outputs Always review and verify AI-generated content, especially for professional, academic, or critical use cases. AI can make mistakes or "hallucinate" information.

docs.title: 📊 Choosing the Right AI Tool

docs.text: AI Timeline A chronological overview of significant milestones in artificial intelligence history, from foundational concepts to modern breakthroughs. 2026 Current year - ongoing developments 2025 Claude Code Released - Claude Code was released in February 2025 as an agentic command line tool that enables developers to delegate coding tasks directly from their terminal. It initially launched as a research preview, and was then made generally available in May 2025 alongside the Claude 4 release. A web-based version followed in October 2025, making it accessible without a local terminal setup. Claude Cowork Released - Desktop applicaton. Available for Mac Silicon only, not Intel-based, and PCs. Claude 4 Series Launch - Anthropic released the Claude 4 family of models, including Claude 4 Opus and Claude 4 Sonnet, representing significant advances in reasoning, coding, and multi-step task completion. 2024 GPT-4o Released - OpenAI released GPT-4o (the "o" stands for "omni"), a multimodal model that can process text, audio, and images with significantly improved speed and reduced costs. Claude 3 Family - Anthropic introduced Claude 3 (Opus, Sonnet, and Haiku), with Claude 3 Opus matching or exceeding GPT-4's performance on many benchmarks. Gemini 1.5 - Google DeepMind released Gemini 1.5 with a breakthrough 1 million token context window, enabling analysis of entire codebases, long documents, and hours of video. AI Safety Institute - Multiple countries established AI Safety Institutes to study and mitigate risks from advanced AI systems. 2023 GPT-4 Launch - OpenAI released GPT-4 in March, demonstrating significant improvements in reasoning, creativity, and multimodal capabilities (text and images). Llama 2 Released - Meta released Llama 2, a collection of open-source large language models ranging from 7B to 70B parameters, democratizing access to powerful AI. Google Bard Launched - Google released Bard (later renamed Gemini), its conversational AI chatbot to compete with ChatGPT. Midjourney V5 - Major advancement in AI image generation quality and prompt adherence. AI Regulation Begins - The EU moved forward with the AI Act, establishing the first comprehensive legal framework for AI regulation. 2022 ChatGPT Released - ChatGPT was introduced on November 30, 2022, by OpenAI. Built on the GPT-3.5 model, it quickly became a massive hit, reaching an estimated 100 million users within about two months of launch — making it one of the fastest-growing consumer applications in history. Stable Diffusion Open-Sourced - Stability AI released Stable Diffusion as open-source, making high-quality text-to-image generation widely accessible. DALL-E 2 Released - OpenAI launched DALL-E 2, demonstrating unprecedented ability to create realistic images from text descriptions. AlphaCode - DeepMind released AlphaCode, an AI system capable of competing in programming competitions at a human competitive level. 2021 Anthropic Founded - The company Anthropic, headquartered in San Francisco, was founded in 2021 by Dario Amodei and Daniela Amodei, along with several other former OpenAI researchers and staff, with a focus on AI safety and research. GitHub Copilot Launch - GitHub and OpenAI launched Copilot, an AI pair programmer that suggests code completions using GPT-3 Codex. DALL-E Introduced - OpenAI introduced DALL-E, the first major text-to-image AI model, demonstrating the potential of multimodal AI. AlphaFold 2 - DeepMind's AlphaFold 2 solved the protein folding problem, a 50-year challenge in biology, with breakthrough accuracy. 2020 GPT-3 Released - OpenAI released GPT-3 with 175 billion parameters, demonstrating unprecedented language generation capabilities and few-shot learning. COVID-19 Accelerates AI Adoption - The pandemic accelerated adoption of AI in healthcare, remote work tools, and drug discovery efforts. 2019 OpenAI Restructuring - OpenAI, in order to attract more funding, created a "capped-profit" subsidiary in 2019. OpenAI is currently in the process of restructuring into a for-profit entity. GPT-2 Released - OpenAI released GPT-2, initially withholding the full model due to concerns about misuse, sparking debate about responsible AI release. BERT by Google - Google introduced BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), revolutionizing natural language understanding and search. 2018 AlphaFold 1 - DeepMind introduced AlphaFold, beginning its groundbreaking work on protein structure prediction. GPT-1 Released - OpenAI released the first Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT), demonstrating the potential of transformer-based language models. Dota 2 AI Victory - OpenAI Five defeated professional Dota 2 players, showcasing reinforcement learning's potential in complex strategic games. 2017 Transformer Architecture - Google researchers published "Attention Is All You Need," introducing the Transformer architecture that would become the foundation for modern LLMs. AlphaGo Zero - DeepMind released AlphaGo Zero, which learned to master Go entirely through self-play without human game data, surpassing previous versions. 2016 AlphaGo Defeats Lee Sedol - DeepMind's AlphaGo defeated world champion Go player Lee Sedol 4-1, a landmark moment showing AI could master complex strategic games once thought beyond computer capability. Word2Vec and Embeddings - Word embedding techniques became mainstream, enabling better representation of language meaning in numerical form. 2015 OpenAI Founded - OpenAI was founded in December 2015 by Sam Altman, Elon Musk, Greg Brockman, Ilya Sutskever, and several others. It was originally established as a nonprofit AI research lab with a mission to ensure artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity. ResNet - Microsoft Research introduced ResNet (Residual Networks), enabling much deeper neural networks and advancing computer vision. 2012 AlexNet and Deep Learning Revolution - Alex Krizhevsky's AlexNet won the ImageNet competition by a large margin, using deep convolutional neural networks and GPUs, sparking the modern deep learning revolution. 2011 IBM Watson Wins Jeopardy! - IBM's Watson defeated human champions in the quiz show Jeopardy!, demonstrating advanced natural language processing and knowledge retrieval. 2006 Geoffrey Hinton's Deep Learning Breakthrough - Geoffrey Hinton and colleagues published work on deep belief networks, reigniting interest in neural networks and launching the deep learning era. 1997 Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov - IBM's Deep Blue became the first computer system to defeat a reigning world chess champion (Garry Kasparov) under tournament conditions. 1980s Neural Networks Resurgence - Backpropagation algorithm was rediscovered and popularized, enabling training of multi-layer neural networks. 1956 Dartmouth Conference - The Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence, organized by John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and others, coined the term "artificial intelligence" and established AI as an academic field. 1950 Turing Test Proposed - Alan Turing published "Computing Machinery and Intelligence," proposing what became known as the Turing Test as a criterion for machine intelligence.
docs.title: Timeline

docs.text: A chronological overview of significant milestones in artificial intelligence history, from foundational concepts to modern breakthroughs.
docs.title: AI Timeline

docs.text: Current year - ongoing developments

Claude Code Released - Claude Code was released in February 2025 as an agentic command line tool that enables developers to delegate coding tasks directly from their terminal. It initially launched as a research preview, and was then made generally available in May 2025 alongside the Claude 4 release. A web-based version followed in October 2025, making it accessible without a local terminal setup. Claude Cowork Released - Desktop applicaton. Available for Mac Silicon only, not Intel-based, and PCs. Claude 4 Series Launch - Anthropic released the Claude 4 family of models, including Claude 4 Opus and Claude 4 Sonnet, representing significant advances in reasoning, coding, and multi-step task completion.

GPT-4o Released - OpenAI released GPT-4o (the "o" stands for "omni"), a multimodal model that can process text, audio, and images with significantly improved speed and reduced costs. Claude 3 Family - Anthropic introduced Claude 3 (Opus, Sonnet, and Haiku), with Claude 3 Opus matching or exceeding GPT-4's performance on many benchmarks. Gemini 1.5 - Google DeepMind released Gemini 1.5 with a breakthrough 1 million token context window, enabling analysis of entire codebases, long documents, and hours of video. AI Safety Institute - Multiple countries established AI Safety Institutes to study and mitigate risks from advanced AI systems.

GPT-4 Launch - OpenAI released GPT-4 in March, demonstrating significant improvements in reasoning, creativity, and multimodal capabilities (text and images). Llama 2 Released - Meta released Llama 2, a collection of open-source large language models ranging from 7B to 70B parameters, democratizing access to powerful AI. Google Bard Launched - Google released Bard (later renamed Gemini), its conversational AI chatbot to compete with ChatGPT. Midjourney V5 - Major advancement in AI image generation quality and prompt adherence. AI Regulation Begins - The EU moved forward with the AI Act, establishing the first comprehensive legal framework for AI regulation.

ChatGPT Released - ChatGPT was introduced on November 30, 2022, by OpenAI. Built on the GPT-3.5 model, it quickly became a massive hit, reaching an estimated 100 million users within about two months of launch — making it one of the fastest-growing consumer applications in history. Stable Diffusion Open-Sourced - Stability AI released Stable Diffusion as open-source, making high-quality text-to-image generation widely accessible. DALL-E 2 Released - OpenAI launched DALL-E 2, demonstrating unprecedented ability to create realistic images from text descriptions. AlphaCode - DeepMind released AlphaCode, an AI system capable of competing in programming competitions at a human competitive level.

Anthropic Founded - The company Anthropic, headquartered in San Francisco, was founded in 2021 by Dario Amodei and Daniela Amodei, along with several other former OpenAI researchers and staff, with a focus on AI safety and research. GitHub Copilot Launch - GitHub and OpenAI launched Copilot, an AI pair programmer that suggests code completions using GPT-3 Codex. DALL-E Introduced - OpenAI introduced DALL-E, the first major text-to-image AI model, demonstrating the potential of multimodal AI. AlphaFold 2 - DeepMind's AlphaFold 2 solved the protein folding problem, a 50-year challenge in biology, with breakthrough accuracy.

GPT-3 Released - OpenAI released GPT-3 with 175 billion parameters, demonstrating unprecedented language generation capabilities and few-shot learning. COVID-19 Accelerates AI Adoption - The pandemic accelerated adoption of AI in healthcare, remote work tools, and drug discovery efforts.

OpenAI Restructuring - OpenAI, in order to attract more funding, created a "capped-profit" subsidiary in 2019. OpenAI is currently in the process of restructuring into a for-profit entity. GPT-2 Released - OpenAI released GPT-2, initially withholding the full model due to concerns about misuse, sparking debate about responsible AI release. BERT by Google - Google introduced BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers), revolutionizing natural language understanding and search.

AlphaFold 1 - DeepMind introduced AlphaFold, beginning its groundbreaking work on protein structure prediction. GPT-1 Released - OpenAI released the first Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT), demonstrating the potential of transformer-based language models. Dota 2 AI Victory - OpenAI Five defeated professional Dota 2 players, showcasing reinforcement learning's potential in complex strategic games.

Transformer Architecture - Google researchers published "Attention Is All You Need," introducing the Transformer architecture that would become the foundation for modern LLMs. AlphaGo Zero - DeepMind released AlphaGo Zero, which learned to master Go entirely through self-play without human game data, surpassing previous versions.

AlphaGo Defeats Lee Sedol - DeepMind's AlphaGo defeated world champion Go player Lee Sedol 4-1, a landmark moment showing AI could master complex strategic games once thought beyond computer capability. Word2Vec and Embeddings - Word embedding techniques became mainstream, enabling better representation of language meaning in numerical form.

OpenAI Founded - OpenAI was founded in December 2015 by Sam Altman, Elon Musk, Greg Brockman, Ilya Sutskever, and several others. It was originally established as a nonprofit AI research lab with a mission to ensure artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity. ResNet - Microsoft Research introduced ResNet (Residual Networks), enabling much deeper neural networks and advancing computer vision.

AlexNet and Deep Learning Revolution - Alex Krizhevsky's AlexNet won the ImageNet competition by a large margin, using deep convolutional neural networks and GPUs, sparking the modern deep learning revolution.
IBM Watson Wins Jeopardy! - IBM's Watson defeated human champions in the quiz show Jeopardy!, demonstrating advanced natural language processing and knowledge retrieval.
Geoffrey Hinton's Deep Learning Breakthrough - Geoffrey Hinton and colleagues published work on deep belief networks, reigniting interest in neural networks and launching the deep learning era.
Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov - IBM's Deep Blue became the first computer system to defeat a reigning world chess champion (Garry Kasparov) under tournament conditions.
Neural Networks Resurgence - Backpropagation algorithm was rediscovered and popularized, enabling training of multi-layer neural networks.
docs.title: 1980s

docs.text: Dartmouth Conference - The Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence, organized by John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and others, coined the term "artificial intelligence" and established AI as an academic field.
Turing Test Proposed - Alan Turing published "Computing Machinery and Intelligence," proposing what became known as the Turing Test as a criterion for machine intelligence.
